snippet: With rural Americans increasingly underserved by legal firms, South Dakota has enacted a financial inducement that could become a model.
abstract: Rural Americans are increasingly without lawyers even as law school graduates are increasingly without jobs;  South Dakota becomes first state to pass law offering lawyers an annual subsidy to live and work in rural areas of the state; move follows growing call for legal education to model itself on medical training that takes advantage of rural areas to increase practical skills and employability of doctors and nurses.
lead_paragraph: With rural Americans increasingly underserved by legal firms, South Dakota has enacted a financial inducement that could become a model.

headline.seo: No Lawyer for 100 Miles, So One Rural State Offers Pay
headline.main: No Lawyer for Miles, So One Rural State Offers Pay
headline.print_headline: No Lawyer for 100 Country Miles, So One Rural State Offers Pay
